title: Change Readiness Assessment
instructions: Read each statement and rate your level of agreement on a scale of 1–5 (1 = Strongly Disagree, 5 = Strongly Agree).

sections.title: Mindset and Openness to Change
questions: I believe change is essential for growth and long-term success.
I view change as an opportunity, not a threat.
I am comfortable stepping outside of my comfort zone.
I trust my ability to adapt when circumstances shift.
I actively seek out new ideas and perspectives to improve my business.

sections.title: Business Awareness and Clarity
questions: I have a clear understanding of where my business currently stands (strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, threats).
I regularly review data and feedback to guide my decisions.
I have clearly defined business goals for the next 12–24 months.
I understand the resources needed to make significant changes (time, money, people).
I know which processes or areas of my business need improvement.

sections.title: Leadership and Decision-Making
questions: I am confident in making difficult decisions when needed.
I communicate changes clearly and consistently to my team.
I encourage feedback and collaboration when planning change.
I hold myself and my team accountable for following through on plans.
I lead by example when adapting to new systems, strategies, or behaviors.

sections.title: Resources and Support
questions: I have the financial resources to invest in meaningful changes.
I have access to mentors, coaches, or advisors when I need guidance.
My team is prepared and capable of handling changes.
I allocate time each week to work on my business, not just in it.
I am willing to hire or outsource to fill skill gaps that could block progress.

sections.title: Resilience and Follow-Through
questions: I remain focused and committed even when challenges arise.
I am patient with the process of change, knowing results take time.
I celebrate progress, even when it’s small.
I review and adjust my plans regularly to stay on track.
I see change as an ongoing process rather than a one-time event.
